name: Ross Wimer
content:
Ross Wimer, FAIA is an American architect, known for integrating the rigor and logic of engineering into his designs.[1] Until October 2013, he was a design director in the Chicago office of Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, LLP. During his tenure at SOM from 1995 to 2013, he created architectural projects in over 20 cities on five continents. Mr. Wimer is a Fellow of the American Institute of Architects. He currently leads AECOM's architecture practice in the Americas.
 The majority of these designs are for large scale mixed-use programs such as Leamouth Peninsula in London, Cayan Tower[2][3] in Dubai, as well as Greenland Group Suzhou Center[4] and White Magnolia Plaza in China. Examples of other work include city planning as in the 93 hectare Marina Bay Master Plan, high-speed rail station design such as Tanggu Rail Hub,[5] airport design as in Changi Airport Terminal 3, and industrial design projects such as the New York Standard Streetlight and door hardware for Valli & Valli SPA.[6]
 Mr. Wimer believes that environmental sustainability and expressive structure help define the aesthetic of architecture, which can be seen in projects such as Zhengzhou Greenland Plaza.[7] His projects have been published widely; exhibited at the Venice Biennale, Art Institute of Chicago,[8] and The Museum of Modern Art in New York; and have received numerous awards, including three Progressive Architecture Awards. Mr. Wimer was featured on the cover of the inaugural issue of Architect Magazine in which he explained that his joy in being an architect is the moral obligation that goes into the project. He believes that it's gratifying to create something that affects people's lives on a daily basis.[9] In his projects, he stresses the importance of exposing the site of a project rather than imposing on it.[10]
 In 1984, Mr. Wimer earned a Bachelor of Arts with Distinction from Yale University followed by a Master of Architecture with Commendation from Harvard University in 1988.
tags: Fellows of the American Institute of Architects
Harvard Graduate School of Design alumni
raw:
American architect
Ross WimerNationalityAmericanOccupationArchitectBuildingsCayan Tower, White Magnolia PlazaProjectsLeamouth Peninsula

Ross Wimer, FAIA is an American architect, known for integrating the rigor and logic of engineering into his designs.[1] Until October 2013, he was a design director in the Chicago office of Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, LLP. During his tenure at SOM from 1995 to 2013, he created architectural projects in over 20 cities on five continents. Mr. Wimer is a Fellow of the American Institute of Architects. He currently leads AECOM's architecture practice in the Americas.
The majority of these designs are for large scale mixed-use programs such as Leamouth Peninsula in London, Cayan Tower[2][3] in Dubai, as well as Greenland Group Suzhou Center[4] and White Magnolia Plaza in China. Examples of other work include city planning as in the 93 hectare Marina Bay Master Plan, high-speed rail station design such as Tanggu Rail Hub,[5] airport design as in Changi Airport Terminal 3, and industrial design projects such as the New York Standard Streetlight and door hardware for Valli & Valli SPA.[6]
Mr. Wimer believes that environmental sustainability and expressive structure help define the aesthetic of architecture, which can be seen in projects such as Zhengzhou Greenland Plaza.[7] His projects have been published widely; exhibited at the Venice Biennale, Art Institute of Chicago,[8] and The Museum of Modern Art in New York; and have received numerous awards, including three Progressive Architecture Awards. Mr. Wimer was featured on the cover of the inaugural issue of Architect Magazine in which he explained that his joy in being an architect is the moral obligation that goes into the project. He believes that it's gratifying to create something that affects people's lives on a daily basis.[9] In his projects, he stresses the importance of exposing the site of a project rather than imposing on it.[10]

Contents

1 Education
2 Professional Associations
3 Key projects
4 See also
5 References


Education[edit]
In 1984, Mr. Wimer earned a Bachelor of Arts with Distinction from Yale University followed by a Master of Architecture with Commendation from Harvard University in 1988.

Professional Associations[edit]
Fellow, American Institute of Architects (FAIA)
Adjunct Professor, Illinois Institute of Technology [11]
Board of Trustees, Graham Foundation [12]
Board of Trustees, Chicago Architecture Foundation [13]
Key projects[edit]

Cayan Tower, Dubai, United Arab Emirates
Leamouth Peninsula, London, United Kingdom
City Lights Design Competition, New York, New York
White Magnolia Plaza, Shanghai, China
Valli & Valli Door Hardware, United States
Tyrol Tower, Wörgl, Austria
Qatar Science Centre, Doha, Qatar
Changi International Airport - Terminal 3, Changi, Singapore
Chicago 2016 Olympic Master Plan, Chicago, Illinois
Crossharbour, London, United Kingdom
The Ledge at Skydeck Chicago, Chicago, Illinois [14]

See also[edit]

Craig Hartman
David Childs
George J. Efstathiou (architect)
Roger Duffy
Skidmore, Owings & Merrill
T.J. Gottesdiener
William F. Baker (engineer)
Philip Enquist

^ "Mixed Greens: an International Survey of state-of-the-art skyscraper design". Skyscraper Museum.

^ "Skidmore design's 30-story window helps skyscraper 'breathe'". Chicago Sun Times. January 17, 2012.

^ "SOM: Ross Wimer". Architype Interviews. August 8, 2011. Archived from the original on April 25, 2012.

^ "Good Design 2007: Hardware". Chicago Athaneum. Archived from the original on 2008-06-20.

^ "Mixed Greens: Ross Wimer, SOM - Environmental Contextualism". Skyscraper Museum.

^ "Infinity Tower Model". The Art Institute of Chicago.

^ "Seven-Point Perspective". Architect Magazine. October 2006.

^ Adams, Nicholas (2007). Skidmore, Owings & Merrill: the Experiment Since 1936. Electa. p. 49.

^ "Ross Wimer, Adjunct Professor". IIT College of Architecture. Archived from the original on 2012-03-22.

^ "2012 Board of Trustees and Staff". Graham Foundation.

^ "Board of Trustees". Chicago Architecture Foundation. Archived from the original on 2012-04-21.

^ "Skywalker: Ross Wimer". Rice Design Alliance. October 23, 2009.
